issues.title: Missing Mandatory Suspension/Expulsion Requirements for Specific Disturbance Activities
issues.description: California Education Code requires specific disciplinary consequences for certain disturbance-related activities. While the policy mentions general disciplinary action and the regulation lists prohibited activities, neither document explicitly addresses the mandatory suspension/expulsion requirements for activities like causing physical injury during a disturbance, possession of weapons during disturbances, or other serious misconduct that may occur during student disturbances.

legal_citations.text: Principal, superintendent of schools, or designee shall recommend expulsion for enumerated offenses including but not limited to causing serious physical injury, possession of weapons, or other violent acts that may occur during disturbances.

issues.required_language: Students who engage in activities during disturbances that fall under Education Code 48900-48900.7 and 48915 shall be subject to suspension and/or expulsion as required by law, including mandatory recommendation for expulsion for serious offenses as specified in Education Code 48915.

issues.title: Missing Due Process Procedures for Disciplinary Actions
issues.description: While both documents reference disciplinary action for students involved in disturbances, neither specifies the due process procedures required before imposing discipline. California law mandates specific procedural safeguards including notice, hearing rights, and appeal processes.

legal_citations.text: Students subject to suspension or expulsion are entitled to due process including written notice of charges, right to hearing, right to present evidence and witnesses, and right to appeal.

issues.required_language: Before imposing disciplinary action for participation in student disturbances, students shall be afforded due process rights as specified in Education Code sections 48911 and 48918, including written notice of charges, opportunity for hearing, and right to appeal as outlined in the district's suspension and expulsion policies.

issues.title: Missing Parent/Guardian Notification Requirements
issues.description: Neither document addresses the mandatory requirement to notify parents/guardians when students are involved in disturbances that may result in disciplinary action, particularly when law enforcement is contacted or when suspension/expulsion proceedings may be initiated.

legal_citations.text: Parent or guardian shall be notified in person or by telephone as soon as possible when student is suspended, and written notice shall be provided.

issues.required_language: Parents/guardians shall be notified immediately when their student is involved in a campus disturbance, particularly when law enforcement assistance is requested or disciplinary action may be taken. Notification procedures shall comply with Education Code section 48911 requirements.

issues.title: Missing Reference to Restorative Justice Alternatives
issues.description: Current California education policy encourages districts to consider restorative justice practices as alternatives or supplements to traditional disciplinary measures. The documents focus solely on punitive responses without mentioning restorative approaches that may be appropriate for some disturbance situations.

legal_citations.text: Suspension or expulsion may be used only when other means of correction fail to bring about proper conduct, and districts are encouraged to use alternatives including restorative justice practices.

issues.required_language: When appropriate and consistent with school safety, the district may consider restorative justice practices and other alternatives to suspension/expulsion for students involved in disturbances, in accordance with Education Code section 48900.5.

issues.title: Outdated Last Review Date
issues.description: Both documents were last reviewed in 2010, which is over 13 years ago. California education law has undergone significant changes since then, particularly regarding student discipline, restorative justice, and school safety protocols. Regular policy review is considered a best practice for compliance.

legal_citations.text: Governing board has authority and duty to establish rules and regulations as necessary for district governance, which implies regular review and updating of policies.

issues.required_language: Policy and regulation should be reviewed and updated to reflect current California education law and best practices.
